bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Maria Teresa Loma viuda de Rojas, December 18, 1947

div1.p: Hench discusses his upcoming visit to Cuba. He sends her a photograph of an old check concerning rental of the Rojas land by the American government, which he received from Kean. Hench hopes that she will carefully preserve the Rojas daybook, which is so important in certifying the site of Camp Lazear.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Maria Teresa Loma viuda de Rojas, December 18, 1947
div1.opener:
December 18, 1947
Senora Teresa Loma Vde de Rojas
207 Calle 17
Vedado,
Havana, Cuba
My dear Senora Rojas:
div1.p:
May I send you oru sincerest Christmas greetings and best wishes
for the New Year.

I was happy to hear that the Cuban Government has made the little
caseta on the Finca San Jose a national monument. I have had some further
correspondence with certain Cuban officials and plan to visit Cuba the first
week in March, 1948, in order to see what more can be done to erect a memorial
on the spot.

I have continued collecting data on the conquest of yellow fever
and among other things received recently from General Kean, who as Major
Kean, was in 1900 the disbursing officer for Major Walter Reed and paid out
the sums of money required for Camp Lazear. I received from him the old
check book which he used for this expense account. I enclose a photograph
copy of one of the items concerning the rent of the land.

I do hope that you will carefully preserve Dr. Rojas daybook. That
is most important, as it, above everything else, helps to certify as to the
authenticity of the Rojas farm as the site of Camp Lazear. Some day this
should be presented to a museum for proper care.

It will be pleasant indeed to visit Cuba again and I do hope that
I will have the privilege of calling upon you and paying my respects.
div1.closer:
Sincerely, P. S. Hench, M. D. PSH:alc
